story: Majorca authorities are to ban owners of apartments from renting the properties to touristsPalma officials announced the proposals to prevent homeowners from letting flats to tourists in a bid to make rent more affordable for local residents.Antoni Noguera, mayor of Palma, said the city &ldquomust be a liveable, following complaints from locals that sky-high rents are forcing them out of the city.Mr Noguera added: &ldquoThe worst thing that can happen is that the inhabitants have to leave their city.Rents in Palma are reported to have increased by 40 percent since 2013 and now tourists are facing a backlash.Anti-tourist protesters declare &lsquoWAR&rsquo on Brit holidaymakers in SpainTOURIST BACKLASH: Magaluf police BAN 90 Britons from pub crawlThe city council will approve the proposal on May 3, which excludes houses that are not in industrial areas, protected lands or near the airport.Antonia Mart&iacuten, general secretary of the Podemos party in Palma, said it is necessary to rationalise the effects of tourism, to take measures.She added that we have listened to people and we have to work to guarantee the right of housing.The rental ban, revealed by ABC, is the latest backlash against tourists in Majorca.The rental ban is the latest backlash against tourists in MajorcaEarlier this year proposals were announced to reduce drunken behaviour in Palma, including banning happy hours and drink offers.Police in Magaluf stopped 90 Britons who were wearing tops with the slogan &ldquospring break invasion from going on a pub crawl.The council said the antics were contrary to tough new regulations against drunken revellers.Campaigners from&nbspArran Paisos Catalans&nbsp- a group against mass tourism - also vowed to continue protesting against holidaymakers in Majorca, despite 12 of its members facing prosecution for a demonstration at a marina in Palma.The protesters &ndash accused of public disorder, damages and threats &ndash let off flames by luxury yachts, threw confetti at tourists and held up banners with anti-tourism messages.The group blames large numbers of tourists in Majorca for causing problems including packed beaches, traffic jams, anti-social behaviour, dirt and noise.&nbsp(Additional reporting by Maria Ortega)

title: bible christianity quran islam islamic holy text
story: CHRISTIE'SA scholar found words from the Bible behind the Arabic onesA close analysis of pictures representing fragments of a Qur&rsquoan manuscript revealed the trace of Coptic letters behind the Arabic words.The finding was the result of a research conducted by French scholar Dr El&eacuteonore Cellard through images of a 'palimpsest page', a manuscript on which later writing has been superimposed on effaced earlier writing, sold by Christie&rsquos more than 10 years ago.After noticing the faint letters, she contacted the auction house which, following further analysis, identified the Coptic text as words of the Old Testament&rsquos Book of Deuteronomy, part of the Torah and the Christian Old Testament.Ms Cellard, who is attached to the College de France, said: &ldquoThis is a very important discovery for the history of the Qur&rsquoan and early Islam.&nbsp                The Bible was WRONG Jesus was NOT born in a stable, claims theologist                Christianity on the BRINK: China BANS bible sales in new crackdown&ldquoWe have here a witness of cultural interactions between different religious communities.Christie&rsquos believe the manuscript is likely to have been produced in Egypt, home of the Coptic community, at the time of the Arab conquest.While the writing style of the Qur&rsquoan scribe dates it to around the eighth century, it&rsquos impossible to state when the almost disappeared Coptic writing was jotted down.The only way to determine how old the fragments are is by conducting Carbon 14 testing, but they could ruin the thin fragments.The auction house said that the palimpsest &ldquoresonate with the historical reality of religious communities in the Near East and as such are an invaluable survival from the earliest centuries of Islam.&nbspChristie&rsquos believe the manuscript is likely to have been produced in EgyptChristie&rsquos specialist Romain Pingannaud added: &ldquoIt&rsquos quite extraordinary.&ldquoOnce you know it&rsquos there, you can only see it, it becomes so obvious.&ldquoWe missed it at the beginning.&ldquoIt&rsquos fascinating, particularly because it&rsquos the only example where you have an Arabic text on top of a non-Arabic text.&ldquoAnd what&rsquos even more fascinating is it is on top of passages from the Old Testament&hellipIt shows the contact between communities in the first centuries of Islam it&rsquos very relevant.&nbspThese are the top biblical archaeology discoveries                    De AgostiniGetty Images1 of 9Mona Lisa of the Galilee: 16 centuries after an earthquake destroyed the Roman city of Sepphoris, a mosaic portrait of an unnamed woman was discovered among the ruinsThe Coptic community is still active in EgyptThe practice of writing over old text was common in the Byzantine and Greek worlds as then it was in use a much stronger material to write, parchment.Mr Pingannaud explained: &ldquoParchment is very strong, it doesn&rsquot suffer too much &ndash it&rsquos sensitive to humidity but very solid.&ldquoAt the time it was erased the parchment was probably like new and it&rsquos only with centuries passing that the ink which sank into the parchment provides this ghost image we see.Those who want to try and grab this extraordinary piece of history will have to be ready to bid above the guide price established by Christie&rsquos, starting from &pound80,000-&pound120,000, on Thursday.&nbsp

story: YONHAP NEWS*Unification flags fly as S. Koreans wish for success of inter-Korean summitSouth Koreans have erected Korean Unification flags across the country ahead of Friday&rsquos meeting, as despot Kim Jong-un meets his Seoul counterpart Moon Jae-in for the first time.The flags will line a section of the road from Tongil Bridge to the DMZ&rsquos Panmunjom, known as the &lsquotruce village&rsquo. The flags are a symbol of hope for reconciliation and reunification after decades of conflict.The landmark meeting will be held in the Joint Security Area, which is a demilitarised zone between the two countries.The meeting comes after weeks of improving diplomatic relations between the two nations, following soaring tensions after North Korea&rsquos missile and nuclear weapons tests last year.The Korean Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) is a meeting point between North and South Korea. Photographer Park Jongwoo gets unprecedented access for a book titled 'DMZ: The Demilitarized Zone of Korea&rsquo, published by Steidl. 1 of 10The flags design utilises a blue silhouette of the Korean Peninsula on a white background. It symbolise the hope of reconciliation and reunification.Lee Sun-Kyung of the South Side Committee, which was launched after the recent lower-level inter-Korean summit, said: &ldquoI wish to see the leaders of the two Koreas make a definite decision and provide a historic watershed.&ldquoDown the road, I hope the summit will lead to brisk inter-Korean exchanges and cooperation, and eventually national reunification.                Trump will go to NORTH KOREA for landmark summit with Kim Jong-un                North Korea BLUFF: Kim freezing nuclear trials ONLY because of THISThe Education Office in the southeastern city of Changwon in South Korea hoisted a unified Korean Peninsula flag on Monday.The office said: &ldquoThe flag raising is to wish for the establishment of a lasting peace mechanism on the Korean Peninsula as a result of the summit.South Korea hopes a successful summit with North Korea will mean country could allow its athletes to take part in the world swimming competition next year.Moon Jae-in will meet Kim on Friday for landmark talks One of the key issues to be discussed in the meeting is North Korea&rsquos controversial nuclear programme, which has been the course of a lot of tensions between the two nations.Another is an official end to the 1950-3 Korean war. title: italy news venice tourism visit bank holiday may
story: Venice is getting ready to manage the number of tourists visiting its most landmarksLocal authorities announced that tourists set to reach popular locations, such as St Marco&rsquos Square or the Rialto Bridge, will be erted to visitor-only routes.This crowd measures aim at relieving the locals from the their day-to-day misery created by thousands of visitors congesting their streets.Mayor Luigi Brunero signed a decree declaring &ldquourgent measures to guarantee public safety, security and liveability in the historic city of Venice.The decree could stop visitors reaching Venice by car, as they could see their right to drive across the only bridge ning over the lagoon from the Italian mainland taken away.The measures will be carried out for the first time during the long weekend ending in May 1, which is a public holiday in Italy and many other countries.&nbsp                Popular attractions which now impose tourist bans                Florence fines tourists &pound8,750 for URINATING on historic landmarksThe mayor called them &ldquoan experiment, suggesting they can be implemented again if successful.He added the decree&rsquos objective was to &ldquomanage pedestrian and water traffic and the flows of people.The high number of tourists heading to the World Heritage city has created such a disruption that the city has long been debating the possibility of setting a limit on the number of visitors who can enter each day.And the congestion suffered by the city is one of the main reasons behind a mass exodus from locals.The historical city recently hit its population&rsquos historic low of 55,000, a fraction of the 190,000 who lived there at the end of the Second World War.&nbspThe historical city recently hit its population&rsquos historic low of 55,000The decree follows the busy Easter long weekend, which saw Venice inundated with more tourists than usual queuing up for up to an hour to get a chance to board the city&rsquos water buses.This is not Venice&rsquos first attempt to regulate the number of visitors.During this year&rsquos Carnival in February, the city kept tabs on the huge crowd using groundbreaking technology including laser sensors.Greek island of Santorini and Dubrovnik in Croatia have already put limits on the number of visitors they are prepared to absorb, afraid they could otherwise lose their charm and see their landscape ruined by mass tourism.&nbsp&nbsp
